title.narrative: Mechanism 17623 - Strengthening HIV Clinical Services in the Republic of Rwanda under PEPFAR

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
This Implementing Mechanism (IM) is a follow on to the Ministry of Health (MoH) Cooperative Agreement, which ends in COP13. In COP14, with USG support, this IM will support planning, implementing, and monitoring of integrated health services, as well as build capacity to strengthen the health system. The IM will provide support for comprehensive national HIV service delivery. The IM will conduct q Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.4: Biomedical Prevention - Injection Safety. Policies, training, waste-management systems, advocacy and other activities to promote medical injection safety, including distribution/supply chain, cost and appropriate disposal of injection equipment and other related equipment and supplies. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

This Implementing Mechanism (IM) is a follow on to the Ministry of Health (MoH) Cooperative Agreement, which ends in COP13. In COP14, with USG support, this IM will support planning, implementing, and monitoring of integrated health services, as well as build capacity to strengthen the health system. The IM will provide support for comprehensive national HIV service delivery. The IM will conduct quality assurance in HIV clinical services, support district health teams, increase sustainability and ownership and capacity building of district and health center teams through training, supervision and mentorship. During FY14, the IM will provide packages of PMTCT, HTC, adult and pediatric C&T, and TB/HIV services at 250 HIV sites, including 163 sites transitioned to the MoH from a previous partner. The IM will be utilized to ensure quality of care, continuum of care via effective linkages, and retention and referral systems. The mechanism will also support the integration of MCH, gender-based and mental health services in HIV programs; and, build human capacity for histopathology and diagnosis of cancers in HIV-positive patients. Finally, the IM will support a health information system that provides quality data that meets the reporting needs of the Government of Rwanda (GoR) and PEPFAR and will be used for program monitoring, evaluation, decision-making, and reporting. The National Disease Surveillance system will be enhanced and an Electronic Medical Record system will be installed and maintained at all MoH/ PEPFAR supported sites. The IM will support activities aligned with the GoR National Strategic Plan including reducing HIV incidence, morbidity and mortality due to HIV/AIDS.

mailing-address.narrative: 2100 Pennsylvania Avenue, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20522, USA

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.
